Catalytic aerobic desulfurization is a promising alternative to hydrodesulfurization or additional technology for deep desulfurization of petroleum distillates containing refractory condensed thiophene derivatives. In this study, a catalyst based on a complex of iron on PAF-30 support modified by ethanolamines was developed. The PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst was characterized using various methods: XRD, FTIR, 13C NMR, low-temperature adsorption-desorption nitrogen, TEM, TGA, UV–vis, XPS and elemental analysis. Compared to a sample prepared by ordinary impregnation of iron salt on a porous support, the chelate complex of iron demonstrated excellent catalytic activity in the oxidation reaction of dibenzothiophene (DBT) by air. The removal rates were achieved at the level of 100, 80 and 75 % for DBT and its mono- and dimethyl-substituted derivatives. The synergistic effect of the PAF-30 mesoporous support, an available complexing ligand and catalytically active iron ions allows you to develop an effective catalyst for aerobic oxidative desulfurization of a sulfur-containing model fuel. High stability of the catalyst during 5 oxidation-regeneration cycles was demonstrated. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic aerobic desulfurization Iron complexes Ethanolamine PAF-30 Air Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction One of the main sources of environmental pollution is sulfur oxides SOx, formed during the combustion of hydrocarbon fuels and emitted by vehicle exhaust gases [1,2]. Sulfur is one of the most common heteroatoms of petroleum fractions, and compounds based on it have a negative impact on the quality of feedstock and products. Sulfur compounds contained in oil and petroleum products lead to corrosion of equipment, cause poisoning of secondary oil refining catalysts, and pose a serious threat to public health [3]. Environmental standards have been introduced worldwide, limiting the sulfur content in gasoline and diesel fuel to 10 ppm [4]. At present, hydrodesulfurization technology, including hydrogenolysis of heteroatomic compounds, is the only industrially implemented method for removing sulfur-containing compounds from petroleum fractions [5]. However, improvements in the technology itself, catalysts, and tightening of process conditions do not allow for an increase in efficiency in the hydrogenation of dibenzothiophene (DBT) and its derivatives due to low reactivity and steric factors [6–9]. Due to the difficulty of removing condensed thiophene derivatives in the process of hydrodesulfurization, desulfurization methods without the use of hydrogen are becoming more widespread. Among the alternative methods of desulfurization, the following methods are most widely used: oxidation [10,11], extraction [12], adsorption [13] and biodesulfuration [14]. The most promising of them is oxidative desulfurization, which has a high degree of desulfurization. This method is a process of oxidation of sulfur compounds present in petroleum oil, followed by the removal of products by adsorption and extraction methods. In the process of oxidation, sulfoxides and sulfones are formed, which have significantly higher polarity compared to the initial compounds. Due to this, they can be easily removed from the hydrocarbon reaction mixture. Hydrogen peroxide, peracids, alkylhydroperoxides, mineral acids, nitrogen oxides, hypochlorites, oxygen or ozone can be used as oxidizing agents in the process of oxidative desulfurization. But recently, special attention has been paid to the aerobic oxidative desulfurization method, thanks to the use of affordable and inexpensive atmospheric oxygen as an oxidizer [15–20]. To activate sufficiently inert oxygen, catalysts of various natures are used: metal oxides [21–24], noble metal nanoparticles [25–28], polyoxometalates [29–35], organometallic complexes [36–42], metal-free systems [43,44]. Organometallic complexes attract great attention due to their structural features, unique physicochemical and redox characteristics and high catalytic properties in various oxidation reactions under fairly mild conditions [45–48]. A study of the literature in the field of aerobic oxidative desulfurization revealed a large number of various publications based on the formation of catalysts from polydentate ligands based on well-known phthalocyananes, porphyrins or salen (N,N’-bis(salicylidene)ethylenediamine) complexes [49,50] and supported metal complexes to increase the heterogenization of the resulting catalyst [51–56]. Despite the high popularity of these compounds in the oxidation of sulfur-containing components of petroleum fractions, their use has limitations associated with the high cost and complexity of the synthesis of tetrapyrrole and arylimine macrocycles. The simplest and most commercially available nitrogen-containing complexing ligands are ethanolamines. Aminoalcohols are attractive examples of chelating bidentate ligands, capable of simultaneously forming several coordination bonds with one central atom. In addition, aminoalcohols are universal ligands with low toxicity and biological activity, high stability, solubility, and low cost [57,58]. Complexes with the simplest representative of aminoalcohols – monoethanolamine – have been well studied in the literature for the synthesis of various organometallic complexes [59–61]. Porous aromatic frameworks (PAF) are a class of porous carriers consisting of aromatic fragments linked together by strong covalent bonds [62,63]. The advantages of using PAFs as a support include a highly developed material surface, a mesh porous structure, and high chemical and thermal stability. The possibility of modification and introduction of various functional groups expands the functionality of using PAFs as adsorbents and supports for catalysts [64–66]. Unlike traditional inorganic supports (silicates, zeolites), PAFs have hydrophobic properties, which significantly improves phase contact in the three-component oxygen-substrate-catalyst system in aerobic oxidative desulfurization reactions [67–69]. In the present work, chelate iron complexes on the surface of the porous PAF-30 support modified with aminoalcohols were obtained and studied as a catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of sulfur-containing compounds. The combination of available aminoalcohols, a transition metal salt and a porous carbon support allows one to obtain a catalyst with high efficiency and stability in the oxidation reaction of various classes of organosulfur compounds by air. The influence of the nature of the nitrogen-containing complexing ligand and the method of catalyst formation on the efficiency of DBT oxidation was studied. In the presence of the PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst, complete oxidation of DBT with air was achieved in 4 h at a temperature of 130 °C. High activity is maintained for 5 cycles with insignificant losses. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of porous aromatic framework (PAF-30) All chemicals used in this work are analytical reagent grade and commercial available. The synthesis of PAF-30 was carried out by the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction between tetrakis(4-bromophenyl)methane and biphenyl-4,4′-diboronic acid according to the procedure[70]. For this, tetrakis(4-bromophenyl)methane was previously obtained according to the procedure [70]. In addition, a procedure was carried out to wash PAF-30 from the residual content of palladium compounds that catalyze the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction [71]. 2.2 Synthesis of porous aromatic framework modified with monoethanolamine (PAF-MEA) and diethanolamine (PAF-DEA) At the next stage, chloromethylation of the PAF-30 was carried out. A suspension of PAF-30 (1.0 g) in methylene chloride (20 mL), pre-cooled to 0 °C, was prepared in a 100 mL double-necked round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a reflux condenser and a dropping funnel. At the same time, dimethoxymethane (7.3 g) and thionyl chloride (11.5 g) were placed in a 25 mL flat-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer. The resulting mixture was stirred for 20 min at 0 °C. The mixture was then added to a suspension of PAF-30 in methylene chloride. Then the solution of tin (IV) chloride (1.25 g) in methylene chloride (5 mL) was added dropwise through dropping funnel to the prepared mixture. The suspension was stirred for 8 h at room temperature. The resultant precipitate was filtered, washed with methylene chloride (2 × 50 mL), tetrahydrofuran (50 mL), a mixture of tetrahydrofuran and hydrochloric acid (1:1 vol.) (2 × 50 mL), water to neutral pH, and tetrahydrofuran (2 × 50 mL). Then, the powder was dried under reduced pressure at a temperature of 60 °C for 6 h. A yellow powder of PAF-CH2Cl was obtained. Synthesis of PAF-MEA and PAF-DEA was accomplished by modification of PAF-CH2Cl with monoethanolamine and diethanolamine using similar methods [71]. PAF-CH2Cl (100 mg), dioxane (6 mL), ethanolamine (0.4 mL), and potassium iodide 10 mg were mixed in a round-bottomed flask and stirred at 70 °C for 3 days. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with acetone (3 × 50 mL), and dried under vacuum overnight. 2.3 Synthesis of iron complex on modified PAF-DEA and PAF-MEA To obtain the iron complex PAF-MEA-Fe and PAF-DEA-Fe, a suspension of PAF-MEA or PAF-DEA (0.35 g) in ethanol was first prepared and stirred for 10 min. In parallel, an alcohol solution of iron nitrate (0.65 g) was prepared, which was then introduced into the suspension of the porous carrier and stirred at room temperature for 10 min, after which it was heated to 80 °C and kept for 2 h. Then the mixture was filtered, washed with ethanol (2 × 25 ml), diethyl ether (2 × 25 ml) and dried in a drying oven in four stages in a temperature mode from 80 to 110 °C for 4 h. Thus, complexes were obtained in which the metal content was 9 wt.%. 2.4 Synthesis of supported iron nitrate on porous aromatic framework (PAF/Fe(NO3)3) The comparison sample was prepared by mixing a suspension of 0.1 g of PAF-30 sample in ethanol and an alcohol solution of 0.19 g of iron nitrate. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h, after which the solvent was completely evaporated in a rotary evaporator under vacuum. The resulting sample was dried at a temperature of 80 to 110 °C with a step of 10 °C for 4 h. 2.5 Oxidation reaction To obtain a model mixture of the substrate with a total sulfur content of 500 ppm, 1.4 mmol (0.258 g) of dibenzothiophene (DBT) were added to 100 ml of decalin. The mixture was stirred and analyzed for component content by GC. Solutions of other sulfur-containing compounds were prepared similarly. The oxidation reaction was carried out in a 50 ml round-bottomed double-necked flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a reflux condenser and a porous glass tube connected to a compressor with an air flow rate of 6 L/h. Schematic of the experimental setup is shown in Fig. S1. The calculated amount of catalyst (0.264 mg/mL) was added to 25 ml of the model mixture in the flask. The flask was then immersed in a bath with silicone oil. The mixture in the flask was continuously stirred throughout the experiment at a constant speed of 650 rpm using a magnetic stirrer at a temperature of 130 °C. 2.6 Analytical equipment X-ray phase analysis was performed on a Rigaku Rotaflex D/max-RC instrument using copper СuKα-radiation with a scanning rate of 2 deg*min–1 in the angular range 2θ = 5 – 100°. Solid-state 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a BRUKER AVANCE-II NMR 400 WB spectrometer operating at the frequencies of 100.6 MHz with using of 4 mm H/X MAS WVT probe. FTIR spectra were recorded in the range of 500–4000 cm−1 on the Nicolet “IR-2000″ spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific) using the method of multiple violation of total internal reflection. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and the characteristics of the porous structure were obtained on the Gemini VII 2390 (V1.02 t) analyzer by Micromeritics. The structure and morphology of the surface were studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a JEOL JEM-2100 (200 kV) device. The chemical composition and distribution of elements in the samples were studied by the EDX method on an EX-24065JGT energy dispersive X-ray analyzer. Elemental analysis using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) of catalysts to determine the metal content was carried out on an X-ray fluorescence wave spectrometer "ARL Perform'X" (Thermo Fisher Scientific, New Wave). The nitrogen and chlorine content of the supports were determined by elemental analysis with a Thermo Flash 2000 CHNS analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in a standard open allund container (V = 85 mm3, d = 6.7 mm) in a stream (20 mL/min) of synthetic air in the temperature range of 30–700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. TGA measurements were carried out on NETZSCH TG 209 F1 thermal weights equipped with an all-round holder with a protective screen and a type P temperature sensor. The absorption spectra were recorded using a Lambda 950 spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer) in the wavelength range from 200 to 1000 nm in the diffuse reflection mod. XPS spectra of the surface layers were recorded on an OMICRON ESCA+ spectrometer (OMICRON, Germany). The analysis of the model mixture and determination of the substrate content was carried out by gas chromatography (GC) using the absolute calibration method on a "Crystal-2000M" chromatograph with a flame ionization detector, Zebron column (L = 30 m, d = 0.32 mm), ZB-1 liquid phase, with temperature programming from 100 °C to 250 °C. The concentration was determined by the change in the relative area of the peaks of the substrate and products (in wt.%). The substrate conversion rate was calculated using the following equation: η = [(C0 Ct)⁄C0] × 100 %, where C0 is the initial concentration of the substrate in the model mixture, and Ct is the concentration of the substrate obtained at time t. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts In the present work, two new heterogeneous catalysts representing a chelate complex of iron fixed on the surface of a porous support PAF-30 modified with aminoalcohols were synthesized. The catalysts were obtained in three stages according to the synthesis scheme shown in Fig. 1 . In the first stage, the structure of the already synthesized PAF-30 was modified with chloromethyl groups by treating it with chloromethyl ether obtained in situ from dimethoxymethane and thionyl chloride in the presence of tin tetrachloride to obtain PAF-CH2 Cl. Then, the second stage of modifying the support structure with nitrogen-containing complexing groups was carried out by treating it with mono- and diethanolamine in a dioxane solution. In the third stage, the reaction of forming a chelate complex of iron with aminoalcohols grafted on the support surface was carried out by mixing an alcohol solution of the metal salt with a suspension of the support. It should be noted that the dispersion of the system changed during the formation of the chelate complex, flocculent particles were formed, and the mother liquor became transparent (Fig. 2 ). The two obtained heterogeneous catalysts contain the same loading of active iron centers, the actual content of which was subsequently determined using XRF. To compare the catalytic properties, a sample of iron nitrate applied to PAF-30 was synthesized. To study the obtained samples, X-ray diffraction analysis was performed (Fig. S2). The X-ray diffraction patterns show broad peaks at 2θ = 8, 15, and 42°, indicating the formation of an amorphous polymer network typical of PAFs [72]. In addition, for the supported PAF/Fe(NO3)3 sample, low-intensity reflections are noted at 12.2 and 22.6°, related to the hydrated iron nitrate phase (JCPDS 01–0124). The X-ray diffraction pattern of the PAF-MEA-Fe sample is low-intensity and does not contain additional reflections, indicating the absence of other crystalline phases on the surface. The absence of intense reflexes may also indicate the presence of iron in a nanocrystalline state [51]. The PAF-30 and PAF-CH2 Cl were studied using solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 3 ). Both materials contain a characteristic set of signals in the region of 110–160 ppm, related to various carbon atoms of the aromatic rings, as well as a low-intensity signal at 66 ppm, corresponding to carbon atoms in the nodal positions of the structure. [52,71]. After modification with chloromethyl groups, a signal appears on the spectrum at 73 ppm, corresponding to the content of –СH2 Cl groups. IR spectra were obtained for the initial PAF-30 and the support modified with chloromethyl groups (Fig. S3), as well as the support modified with aminoalcohols and the PAF-MEA-Fe catalysts (Fig. 4 ). All spectra contain absorption bands at 1600, 1485, 1005, 808, 780–662 cm−1, typical for PAFs. [73]. The introduction of functional groups and iron salts onto the surface and into the pores of the material does not lead to a significant change in the intensities and frequency values of the characteristic vibrations of the framework. The vibrations of the bond of amino groups in different degrees of substitution (NH and CN) and the vibrations of COH contained in MEA and DEA are not observed in the range of 1000–1400 cm−1, which can be explained by their low intensity. The feature at 520 cm−1 was assigned to Fe–O stretching modes in the PAF-MEA-Fe and PAF-DEA-Fe samples [53]. The IR spectra of the catalysts with the chelate iron complex have an identical absorption band, which indicates the identity of the modified carbon framework in the obtained materials. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the initial PAF-30 and the support modified with chloromethyl groups (Fig. S4), as well as the support modified with ethanolamines and the final catalysts, have a hysteresis loop characteristic of mesoporous materials (Fig. 5 ). [54] In the case of modified materials, a less pronounced hysteresis loop is observed, which indicates a decrease in the proportion of micro- and mesopores. These results are also confirmed by a decrease in the specific surface area calculated using both the t-Plot and BET models (Table 1 ). In the case of a material modified with chloromethyl groups (Table S1) and ethanolamines, there is a slight increase in the specific surface area from 483 to 523 m2/g and up to 588 m2/g (after MEA grafting), which may be due to the leaching of residual compounds during synthesis and intermediate washing. At the same time, a strong decrease in textural characteristics to 24 m2/g is observed during the modification of DEA, which may be due to side condensation processes during the modification of PAF-30 and the formation of hydrogen bonds between OH groups inside the pores of materials, preventing the diffusion of nitrogen molecules. After complexation with iron salts, the type of isotherm of the studied samples is preserved. It should be noted that the chlorine content was analyzed by XRF, and the nitrogen content was analyzed by CHNS (Table 2 ). For the chloromethylated sample, the chlorine content corresponds to 6.9 wt.% with a theoretically calculated 7 wt.%. It is important to note that the PAF-CH2 Cl sample may contain, in addition to the target sample, residual amounts of the initial reagent - thionyl chloride and tin chloride. To form a chelate complex, it is necessary to create accessible complexation centers. For this purpose, PAF-30 functionalized with ethanolamine by an alkylation reaction was obtained, in which the nitrogen content corresponded to 1.3 wt.% for PAF-MEA and 1.7 % for PAF-DEA. As can be seen, the nitrogen content is noticeably lower than the chlorine content in the previous PAF-CH2 Cl sample, which may be due to the content of impurity chlorine particles. It is important to note that residual amounts of impurities can be washed out during subsequent modifications of the base material and its washing. It is possible that the modified PAF-MEA and PAF-DEA samples may also contain residual amounts of PAF-CH2 Cl. However, it is suggested that the completeness of the reaction was achieved in full, since the alkylation reaction was carried out in excess of aminoalcohols. According to the results of elemental analysis (XRF), the content of the iron is consistent with the theoretically calculated value and is approximately 9 wt.% (Table 3 ). To study the morphology of the samples, using PAF-MEA-Fe as an example, TEM micrographs were obtained (Fig. 6 ), which show an amorphous structure with spherical globules with a diameter of 100–200 nm. Darkened areas are concentrated at the edges and inside the amorphous globules of the studied sample, indicating the deposition of metal on the surface and in the pores of the support. The same morphology is observed in typical PAF-30. The energy dispersive X-ray mapping (EDX) results for the PAF-MEA-Fe are shown in Fig. 7 . The images of the sample show that nitrogen is uniformly distributed over the surface of the carbon support, just as iron is uniformly distributed relative to nitrogen. However, individual areas saturated with iron atoms are noted, which may be due to the formation of agglomerates based on iron salts. The thermal stability of the samples was studied using TGA, the results of which are shown in Fig. 8 A. The initial weight loss of the samples at temperatures <150 °C is due to the desorption of adsorbed water. In the temperature range of 150–400 °C, the weight loss of the samples occurs due to the decomposition of functional groups. The onset of structural decomposition of PAF-30 on the TGA curves is observed at temperatures above 400 °C, indicating high thermal stability of PAF. At temperatures of 575 °C for the PAF-30 sample and 525 °C for the PAF-MEA sample, the weight loss almost ceases, with the residue content being <5 wt.%. The decomposition of the PAF-MEA-Fe sample ceases at 560 °C, the mass of the dry residue is 27 wt.%, which corresponds to the mass of iron oxide Fe2O3, which is in good agreement with the results of elemental analysis (in terms of pure iron, it is 9.17 wt.%). Fig. 8B shows the UV–vis spectra of the modified PAF-30 samples and its iron chelate complex. The absorption band at 300 nm in the UV–vis spectrum for both samples corresponds to the conjugated aromatic system of the PAF-30 framework [74]. The spectrum of the final catalyst is a mixture of two peaks: the PAF-30 support and the iron ion. Using the deconvolution method, an absorption band near 500 nm was isolated, which corresponds to Fe3+ ions [75]. Additionally, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was studied, a survey spectrum of the PAF-MEA-Fe sample (Fig. S5) and spectra of its Fe2p, N1 s (Fig. 9 ) and C1 s, O1 s (Fig. S6) profiles were obtained. The Fe2p profile contains two peaks with characteristic satellites that correspond to the Fe3+ state: the first one belongs to the 2p3/2 orbital with a binding energy of 711.1 eV and the second one to the 2p1/2 orbital with a binding energy of 725.4 eV [53]. The obtained Fe2p profile agrees well with the UV–vis spectrum, where the only state of iron is also Fe3+. The N1 s spectrum for PAF-MEA-Fe is divided into two components at binding energies of 399.8 and 407.1 eV, corresponding to nitrogen in the C–NH–C and –NO3 states [76,77]. The obtained data confirm the grafting of monoethanolamine on the PAF surface with the formation of secondary substituted nitrogen. The C1 s profile contains peaks with binding energies of 284.2 and 285 eV, corresponding to CC in the aromatic framework and CN from the complexing ligand [77]. The peak with a binding energy of 286.4 eV corresponds to CO, namely, alcohol groups in MEA and DEA. The high-resolution O1 s spectrum shows four peaks at 533.5, 532.6, 531.5 and 530 eV, corresponding to adsorbed water, CO alcohol groups and hydrated iron compounds [53,78]. 3.2 Study of catalytic activity The results of aerobic oxidation of dibenzothiophene (DBT) as a model sulfur-containing substrate in the presence of the synthesized catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 . First, the influence of the nature of the nitrogen-containing complexing ligand (mono- and diethanolamine) and the method of catalyst formation (application of an iron salt and formation of an iron chelate complex) on the conversion of DBT were studied. As can be seen, complete oxidation of DBT in the presence of the PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst is achieved in 4 h. In the presence of the PAF-DEA-Fe catalyst, only 80 % conversion can be achieved in the same time. It is worth noting that the catalytic curve in the case of using monoethanolamine as a binding ligand has an S-shape, which is standard for this reaction [79]. When using a catalyst containing diethanolamine, a flat region is observed on the catalytic curve during the first 3 h. In both cases, the presence of an induction period is associated with the energy barrier to the activation of atmospheric oxygen caused by the formation of alkyl hydroperoxide from decalin in presence of iron ions. Solvent participates in the system as a carrier of active oxygen [80]. The significantly low activity of the catalyst with diethanolamine may be due to the low textural characteristics. The possible occurrence of a side condensation process during the synthesis of the PAF-DEA-Fe sample probably led to a decrease in the specific surface area and deterioration of both the dispersion of the active phase on the support and the diffusion of the substrate onto the catalyst surface. It should be noted that the initial PAF-30 support does not exhibit catalytic activity, demonstrating conversion at the level of a blank experiment without a catalyst. Iron nitrate physically deposited on a non-functionalized support (PAF/Fe(NO3)3) exhibits slightly higher activity than the blank experiment. This is explained by the presence of active iron centers on the material, but their poor dispersion due to the ineffective deposition of iron nitrate from a polar solvent onto the hydrophobic surface of PAF-30. In this case, the non-uniform deposition is represented by agglomerates of iron salt, which can be washed out from the support. To study the patterns of DBT oxidation, the most active catalyst PAF-MEA-Fe was selected. With an increase in the stirring rate from 450 to 650 rpm, the substrate conversion increases (Fig. 11 ), and then reaches a plateau, which is probably due to the achievement of a uniform distribution of the catalyst in the reaction system and the transition of the heterogeneous catalysis process from the diffusion region to the kinetic region. In this regard, the optimal stirring rate was chosen to be 650 rpm. To study the effect of the catalyst dosage on the DBT conversion, a series of reactions was carried out with the PAF-MEA-Fe mass varied from 0.068 to 2 mg/mL (Fig. 12 ). The maximum conversion was achieved at catalyst dosages of 0.132 and 0.264 mg/mL. A decrease in the dosage to 0.068 mg/mL slightly reduced the substrate oxidation rate, which may be due to a decrease in the concentration of active catalytic centers. With an increase in the dosage to 0.665 g/mL and higher, the DBT conversion after 1 h became significantly lower. This may be due to the fact that the excessively high iron content begins to interfere with the accumulation of alkyl peroxides formed during the reaction under the action of atmospheric oxygen in the decalin medium. Due to the highest DBT conversion rate throughout the entire time, a dosage of 0.264 mg/mL was chosen as the optimal one. The dependence of DBT conversion on the reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 13 А. According to the obtained data, with increasing temperature, DBT conversion increases as a result of an increase in the rate of formation of active oxygen-containing particles and, as a consequence, the oxidation rate of the sulfur substrate increases. The most obvious catalytic effect when using the PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst is observed at a temperature of 130 °C, where the difference between the blank and catalytic experiments is greatest. At 120 °C in the presence of a catalyst, the DBT conversion in 4 h did not exceed 48 %, and the blank experiment showed a value close to 0 %. At 140 °C, the DBT conversion value in the experiment without a catalyst is excessively high due to the occurrence of side reactions of solvent oxidation, which leads to a decrease in the selectivity of the process [81]. Therefore, the reaction should be carried out at a temperature not exceeding 130 °C, which was chosen for further research. The reaction rate constants are calculated from the obtained kinetic temperature dependences, which resulted in an activation energy equal to 43 kj/mol (Fig. S7, Table S2). The variation of the air flow rate has an identical trend to that described in the literature [82]. The most efficient distribution of oxygen in the system occurs at an air flow rate of 6 L/h. This air flow rate eliminates the possibility of oxidizer loss and ensures efficient oxygen consumption in the reaction system as a result of longer contact with the substrate molecule and the catalyst (Fig. 13B). The study of the nature of various sulfur substrates of petroleum origin is shown in Fig. 14 A. The difference in the oxidation rates of condensed thiophene derivatives can be associated with steric factors and electron density on the sulfur atom, the indices of which decrease in the following series: 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene Me2DBT (5.760) > 4-methyldibenzothiophene MeDBT (5.759) > DBT (5.758) > benzothiophene BT (5.739) > thiophene Th (5.696) > dodecyl mercaptan CH3(CH2)11SH. It is shown that branched molecules are less reactive, namely, alkyl-substituted DBT molecules are oxidized with lower efficiency [83]. From the obtained results it can be concluded that the obtained catalyst will be more effective in oxidative desulfurization of heavy fractions of oil, where the main sulfur-containing compounds are dibenzothiophene and its derivatives. The possibility of catalyst reuse was assessed using regenerated PAF-MEA-Fe. For this purpose, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture after oxidation by centrifugation and regenerated. The regeneration process involves three-fold washing with ethyl alcohol, after which the catalyst is dried in a drying oven to constant weight at 110 °C. Then the catalyst is returned to the reaction system and used in the next cycle. The study of multiple use should be carried out specifically with the regenerated catalyst, since the filtered catalyst after the reaction contains adsorbed decalin oxidation products, which, when subsequently reused, can affect the efficiency of substrate oxidation. For a more detailed consideration of the effect of regeneration on the properties of the catalyst, a list of physico-chemical analyses of regenerated PAF-MEA-Fe after one reaction cycle was carried out: IR spectroscopy (Fig. S8), X-ray diffraction (Fig. S9) and TGA analysis (Fig. S10). Based on the results obtained, the preservation of the catalyst structure has been confirmed. Recyclization of PAF-MEA-Fe during 5 oxidation cycles demonstrates high stability of the synthesized catalytic system, namely, the removal of the sulfur substrate is maintained at a constant level with the achievement of 99 % conversion (Fig. 14B). A slight drop can be associated with mechanical losses. Thus, the obtained catalyst based on the iron complex PAF-MEA-Fe demonstrated good stability and the ability to retain activity in recycling. 3.3 Mechanism in the presence PAF-MEA-Fe Based on the literary data and the results of the experiments, the proposed mechanism of aerobic oxidation DBT is presented (Fig. 15 ). The oxidation process is based on the activation of atmospheric oxygen and initiation of the oxidation reaction by iron ions [63]. At the initial stage, in the presence of a catalyst, autooxidation of the solvent, decalin, occurs with intermediate generation of hydroperoxide as an active oxygen carrier [60]. As a result of this process, an oxidation–reduction pair Fe3+/Fe2+ is formed in the system, which, through electron transfer, accelerates the oxygen activation process. Due to this, radicals are actively formed and accumulated in the reaction system, the dominant role among which is played by the superoxide radical. When the concentration of the resulting radicals begins to exceed the concentration of the decaying particles, the superoxide radical begins to interact with the DBT molecule with the formation of an intermediate sulfoxide first, and then sulfone as a product of complete oxidation. The catalytic cycle is closed as a result of continuous acts of reduction-oxidation of the catalyst under the action of the resulting radicals. Thus, the PAF-30 support, which has a highly developed surface, mesoporous structure and hydrophobic nature, provides a reduction in mass diffusion restrictions, improving mass transfer and contact of interacting phases. Modification of the surface and pores of the support with ethanolamine makes it possible to create a stable and highly effective complex with iron salts by forming a chelate complex. Amino alcohols bind active metal centers well, ensuring their stabilization and preventing their leaching during aerobic oxidation over several cycles. Active particles based on iron ions are excellent oxygen activators, reducing the energy barrier of the reaction, initiating the formation of radicals and stimulating the oxidation of the organic substrate. The synergistic effect of the PAF-30 support, an available modifier and catalytically active iron ions makes it possible to develop an effective catalyst for the aerobic oxidative desulfurization of sulfur-containing model fuels. Comparative characteristics of the developed PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst with literature data are presented in Table S4. 4 Conclusion Thus, a heterogeneous catalyst based on an iron chelate complex containing covalently grafted aminoalcohols - mono– and diethanolamines in the structure of a porous PAF-30 support was successfully obtained and characterized by a complex of physico-chemical methods. A highly developed surface and porous structure (359 m2/g, pore diameter 5 nm) were shown, the carbon nature of the support was proved by 13C NMR, and the successful covalent grafting of aminoalcohols to the surface of the PAF-30 support and the formation of a chelate complex with iron nitrate were confirmed. The homogeneous distribution of iron ions on the surface of the modified support is demonstrated. The electronic state of iron was studied by the method of XPS and UV–vis spectroscopy. It has been shown that iron is probably in the form of Fe3+ ions and in the hydrated form of FeOOH. The synergistic effect of the porous support PAF-30, the available complexing ligand and active trivalent iron was shown in the oxidation reaction of DBT by air. The highly developed and hydrophobic nature of the support provides enhanced mass transfer, modification with ethanolamines allows the formation of a chelated metal complex, and the highly dispersed state of iron ions contributes to the effective activation of atmospheric oxygen. A 100 % conversion of DBT was achieved in the presence of PAF-MEA-Fe at a temperature of 130 °C in 4 h. A possible mechanism of the aerobic oxidation reaction is proposed, where the formation of the redox pair Fe3+/Fe2+ plays a key role in the activation of oxygen to O2 •‑. The high stability of the PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst during 5 oxidation-regeneration cycles has been demonstrated. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic aerobic desulfurization is a promising alternative to hydrodesulfurization or additional technology for deep desulfurization of petroleum distillates containing refractory condensed thiophene derivatives. In this study, a catalyst based on a complex of iron on PAF-30 support modified by ethanolamines was developed. The PAF-MEA-Fe catalyst was characterized using various methods: XRD, FTIR, 13C NMR, low-temperature adsorption-desorption nitrogen, TEM, TGA, UV–vis, XPS and elemental analysis. Compared to a sample prepared by ordinary impregnation of iron salt on a porous support, the chelate complex of iron demonstrated excellent catalytic activity in the oxidation reaction of dibenzothiophene (DBT) by air. The removal rates were achieved at the level of 100, 80 and 75 % for DBT and its mono- and dimethyl-substituted derivatives. The synergistic effect of the PAF-30 mesoporous support, an available complexing ligand and catalytically active iron ions allows you to develop an effective catalyst for aerobic oxidative desulfurization of a sulfur-containing model fuel. High stability of the catalyst during 5 oxidation-regeneration cycles was demonstrated.
